commander.previous_service: Czechoslovak Army officer, fled after German occupation 1939

fuel_reserves.notes: Limited fuel stocks during Tobruk siege. Dependent on fortress supply system via Royal Navy convoys.

ammunition_stocks.notes: Ammunition rationing during siege. Resupply via Royal Navy 'Tobruk Ferry Service' every 3-4 days.

water_reserves.notes: Water severely rationed in Tobruk - 2 pints per man per day. Limited washing, no bathing.

rations.notes: Rations supplemented from Tobruk fortress stocks. Vegetables scarce, mostly tinned food.

medical_facilities.notes: Serious casualties evacuated by Royal Navy to Alexandria. Battalion treated minor wounds internally.

communications.notes: Communications coordinated through Polish Carpathian Brigade HQ. Runner system used extensively in defensive positions.

operational_readiness.vehicle_status: 70% operational (high breakdown rate due to desert conditions and siege stress)
operational_readiness.morale: High despite casualties and harsh conditions
operational_readiness.notes: Battalion suffered 14 KIA, 26 severely wounded, 55 lightly wounded during 51 days of combat (158 total days in Tobruk). Withdrawn end of December 1941 for rest and reorganization.

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry battalion organized on British model for garrison/defensive operations. Primary role during Q4 1941 was static defense of Tobruk fortress western sector, regarded as most endangered position.
special_capabilities: Experienced in desert warfare and siege conditions after 158 days in Tobruk
High morale and cohesion despite casualties
Effective integration with Polish Carpathian Brigade
Proven defensive tactics against German-Italian assaults
tactical_innovations: Adapted Czech military doctrine to British equipment and tactics
Effective use of limited resources during prolonged siege
Coordination with multinational garrison (Australian, British, Polish, Indian units)
known_issues: Limited mobility - primarily static defensive role

tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Unit adapted to siege warfare conditions including water rationing (2 pints/day), extreme heat, continuous air attacks, and limited resupply. Defensive positions fortified with sandbags, mines, and wire obstacles.

validation.notes: Data compiled from web research on Czechoslovak 11th Infantry Battalion service at Tobruk. Personnel and equipment based on standard British battalion TO&E 1941 with adjustments for siege conditions. Casualty figures (14 KIA, 26 severe, 55 light wounds) from primary sources. Battalion served 158 days in Tobruk fortress (51 days combat), defending western sector under Polish Carpathian Brigade command. Withdrawn end December 1941, transferred to 38th Indian Infantry Brigade, later reorganized as 200th Czech Light AA Regiment (May 1942). Confidence reduced to 78% due to limited battalion-level primary source documentation.
